title: Push for dedicated aircraft viewing area at Adelaide Airport | ABC NEWS
description: Adelaide plane spotters say it’s getting harder to get unobstructed views of aircraft because of development around the airport and they want Adelaide Airport to open a dedicated viewing area, like those at the Sydney, Perth and Brisbane airports. title: Why did the French military dump tonnes of cocaine into the sea?  | The World | ABC NEWS
description: The French military has released video of it intercepting a ship carrying five tonnes of cocaine near French Polynesia. The haul is thought to be worth more than $1 billion and bound for Australia, but was dumped into the sea before the ship's crew were allowed to sail away. The President of French Polynesia has told the ABC that overcrowded prisons meant they couldn't prosecute the crew. Steve Symon is Chair of New Zealand's Ministerial Advisory Group on Transnational, Serious, Organised Crime, and said the surge in larger shipments of drugs through the Pacific is proving hard for Pacific nations to address. title: Keir Starmer survives pressure to resign over Epstein-Mandelson links | ABC NEWS
description: British Prime Minister Keir Starmer has resisted calls to resign and survived a leadership crisis sparked by revelations from the Epstein files about his former ambassador to the US, Peter Mandelson.  The leader mounted a rallying cry to his cabinet ministers in a private meeting at 10 Downing Street.  Meanwhile, the royal family continues to face scrutiny over the former prince Andrew’s relationship with the late convicted sex trafficker Jeffrey Epstein. title: Netanyahu makes seventh trip to meet Trump ahead of US-Iran nuclear talks | ABC NEWS
description: Benjamin Netanyahu is set to meet Donald Trump ahead of talks for a nuclear deal between Washington and Tehran. It's the seventh trip the Israeli prime minister has made to the US in Trump's second term.  The Israeli leader wants Iran to abandon its uranium enrichment program and for limits to be imposed on Tehran's ballistic missile arsenal.  Speculation is also emerging over whether the US will criticise the Netanyahu government’s plans to expand Israeli settlements in the West Bank, after UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres branded the proposal as a breach of international law. title: Why police clashed with Sydney protesters | ABC News Daily podcast
description: The protesters came in force, but what began peacefully descended into chaos.    Around 6,000 people had gathered to condemn the visit to Sydney by the Israeli president but there were violent clashes with police after they were ordered to disperse.   Today, law professor Luke McNamara from the University of New South Wales on the new protest laws brought in after the Bondi attack and why he thinks the Labor government has gone too far.    Featured:    Luke McNamara, Professor in the Faculty of Law and Justice and the University of New South Wales

title: FBI releases doorbell camera video of masked man at Nancy Guthrie's home | ABC NEWS
description: The FBI has released the first images of a man they wish to identify in relation to the suspected abduction of the mother of US TV host Savannah Guthrie. FBI director Kash Patel posted four images on X he said were of a man who appeared to have tampered with Nancy Guthrie's home camera on the morning of her disappearance. Mr Patel said authorities had been working to recover images or video that "may have been lost, corrupted, or inaccessible due to a variety of factors — including the removal of recording devices." Authorities believe Nancy Guthrie was taken against her will from her house just outside Tucson, Arizona. She was last seen there on January 31 and reported missing the next day after not attending church. title: Indonesian soldiers set to join international stabilisation force in Gaza | ABC NEWS
description: Indonesia says it’s preparing to deploy thousands of soldiers to Gaza as it joins the international stabilisation force. It’s the first foreign nation to do so, as part of phase two of the ceasefire agreement brokered by the US. title: Homeland security officials defend ICE shootings at congressional hearing | ABC NEWS
description: Top officials from the US Department of Homeland Security have defended the conduct of ICE agents who killed US citizens Renee Good and Alex Pretti during an immigration crackdown in Minneapolis.  Acting ICE Director Todd Lyons refused to apologise for labelling Ms Good a domestic terrorist while he was grilled in a congressional hearing on Capitol Hill.  The Trump administration is seeking a funding package for homeland security operations, but Democrats are mounting a fierce challenge and demanding demanding changes to immigration enforcement tactics. title: Rents surging beyond wage growth creating record unaffordability | ABC NEWS
description: A new report from Cotality has found rents have been surging well beyond wage growth. Leo Patterson Ross from the Tenants Union NSW says rental affordability is usually stable and the surge in rental growth means many people will simply lose their homes and communities to get something more affordable. title: Herzog visit sets back fight against antisemitism: Josh Bornstein | ABC NEWS
description: Human rights lawyer Josh Bornstein from the Jewish Council of Australia says one of the main driver's of antisemitism in Australia is the collective punishment of Australian Jews for the acts of Israel in response to the perception that Israel has collectively punished Palestinians for the acts of Hamas. He says that the visit of Isaac Herzog to Australia conflates the actions of Israel with Australian Jews and hurts the fight against antisemitism. title: Uber agrees to external review after case over guide dog refusals | ABC NEWS
description: Uber has agreed to an external review of its operations after settling a case brought by a Victorian woman who was refused more than 30 rides while travelling with a guide dog. Paula Hobley and her legal team are hoping to use the review as an opportunity to fix a problem they say has become “endemic”. Disability affairs reporter Nas Campanella discusses the case. title: Serious incidents at daycares on the rise, public school enrolments at record low | ABC NEWS
description: The Productivity Commission's annual report on government services has found serious incidents endangering children at daycare centres have reached a record high. Meanwhile, it’s also found public school enrolments are at a record low despite cost-of-living pressures, with more parents turning towards private education. title: $220 million plan to end Indigenous family violence announced | ABC NEWS
description: Racheal Dungay from the Ngarra Aboriginal Corporation says a new $220 million plan to address domestic violence against First Nations women and children would have a "massive impact" on services such as hers, which have been constrained by short-term funding cycles.  The 10-year road map Our Ways — Strong Ways — Our Voices, released this week, was developed by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples in collaboration with Australian and state and territory governments.
